responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Application Version Disclosure
    analysis: |
      The plugin sends the result of the application detection script to the Jenkins controller, which then includes it in the build log.
      An attacker with access to the build log can therefore see the output of the application detection script, which may include sensitive information such as the versions of installed applications.
    cwe: CWE-200
    function_names:
      - org.jenkinsci.plugins.appdetector.task.AppDetectionTask.call
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/appdetector/task/AppDetectionTask.java
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: OS Command Injection in Application Detection Script
    analysis: |
      The application detection script is executed on the Jenkins agent, and can execute arbitrary shell commands using the `runExternalCommand` method.
      If an attacker can control the content of this script, they can execute arbitrary commands on the Jenkins agent.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names:
      - org.jenkinsci.plugins.appdetector.util.Utils.runExternalCommand
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/appdetector/util/Utils.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Insufficiently Protected Credentials in Application Detection Script
    analysis: |
      The application detection script has access to the build environment, which may include sensitive credentials.
      If these credentials are not properly protected, they could be leaked through the application detection script.
    cwe: CWE-522
    function_names:
      - org.jenkinsci.plugins.appdetector.task.AppDetectionTask.call
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/appdetector/task/AppDetectionTask.java
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Application Version Disclosure
leads.analysis:
The plugin sends the result of the application detection script to the Jenkins controller, which then includes it in the build log.
An attacker with access to the build log can therefore see the output of the application detection script, which may include sensitive information such as the versions of installed applications.

leads.headline: OS Command Injection in Application Detection Script
leads.analysis:
The application detection script is executed on the Jenkins agent, and can execute arbitrary shell commands using the runExternalCommand method.
If an attacker can control the content of this script, they can execute arbitrary commands on the Jenkins agent.

leads.headline: Insufficiently Protected Credentials in Application Detection Script
leads.analysis:
The application detection script has access to the build environment, which may include sensitive credentials.
If these credentials are not properly protected, they could be leaked through the application detection script.
